body:
Netrw is not bad but it shouldn't be the default file manager for this reasons:
- adds over 300 tags to help file
- has no sane method of updating when bundled by default (realistically an over 10 000 line plugin should be updateable easily)
- needs some additional plugins to behave reasonably (like vim-vinegar)
- has some (long standing) bugs
- no fresh github mirror for use with plugin managers
- slows down startup

On the plus side of netrw:
- very comprehensive file manager
- has insane nearly 4000 lines documentation file (although intimidating for most i think)

Dirvish:
- is lean
- not buggy
- does most commonly used features netrw + vinegar ootb

On minus sides:
- hooks into netrw commands? ie. doesnt offer its own :H and :Vexplore, etc if netrw isnt installed, although you can use `:e .` or `:sp .` etc.
- doesn't offer gx command

Afaik from my grepping it seems that the only thing that depends on this plugin is some spellchecking in `spell-SpellFileMissing`.

In the same vein vimball plugin should be dropped. From my testing after removing netrw on vanilla vim and cleaning help tags i can't see any breakage.

comment_data.body:
I think dirvish is mostly meant for navigation. netrw is huge and has lots of issues, but it also does tons of stuff that dirvish doesn't (ssh support for editing remote files, opening URIs, etc.)

I can't see any plugin supercede netrw any time soon.

if it not a bug,we should keep the plugin just same as vim
~ we can provide a var for user to disable it ,but it should be enabled as default
I think the default plugins should be in `runtime/opt/...`
neovim has strong default, can it works well with out runtime?if so , what the should be put in to runtime
what about just adding dirvish to the standard plugins?
@josephholsten please no. There should be removal of features from `runtime`, not adding them.
Consider removing netrw in favor of nothing. If somebody wants a file explorer can add a plugin. Also the tar and zip plugins.

> Consider removing netrw in favor of nothing. If somebody wants a file explorer can add a plugin. Also the tar and zip plugins.

Discussed in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1507 . These plugins are autoload'd so the cost is small, and the gain doesn't offset the inconvenience / user confusion. Though we're open to replacing them if there were a high-quality alternative.

Not sure if it's considered mature enough yet, or if this issue is even still worthy of being open, but I would posit https://github.com/elihunter173/dirbuf.nvim as an alternative to dirvish if one is still looking for a plugin to replace `netrw`.

It's small, nimble, focused, and has a nice dirvish-like behaviour whilst being better suited for the lua age.

I'm not connected with it in any way except being a keen user.

> would posit https://github.com/elihunter173/dirbuf.nvim as an alternative to dirvish if one is still looking for a plugin to replace `netrw`.
> 
> It's small, nimble, focused, and has a nice dirvish-like behaviour whilst being better suited for the lua age.

hmm.. Dirvish intentionally avoids this kind of thing: https://github.com/elihunter173/dirbuf.nvim/blob/main/lua/dirbuf/planner.lua

@justinmk sure. I'm "just" a user so not necessarily expressing an opinion on the internals of `dirbuf.nvim`. Just highlighting that I think it makes a nice replacement for netrw (and to me feels like a next-gen dirvish). Personally I'd still like to see netrw untangled/removed from the default NeoVim build, and allow the user to decide on the file manager, but understand that's already been discussed and decided against.
I will gladly jettison netrw into the sun simply because it does not honor `:bd`. There is no reason such an obnoxious plugin needs to come standard.

Do we actually know who maintains netrw? Perhaps we should also coordinate with vim to make it less “default” and more “shipped alongside”.I’m trying to imagine what that would look like.But I haven’t missed netrw once since switching to dirvish.  On Sep 25, 2022, at 18:01, Noah Pederson ***@***.***> wrote:﻿
I will gladly jettison netrw into the sun simply because it does not honor :bd. There is no reason such an obnoxious plugin needs to come standard.

—Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID: ***@***.***>
Some plugin or configuration may use netrw.  Because it is builtin.  So this is harder problem.

> Do we actually know who maintains netrw? 

That's listed at the top of the files: Charles E. Campbell, aka [Dr. Chip](http://www.drchip.org/astronaut/vim/index.html#NETRW)

It's still not quite clear what the actual harm is in shipping it since it's 1. actively maintained and 2. taken verbatim from Vim.

If you don't want it, you can always `let g:loaded_netrwPlugin = 1`, same as any bundled plugin?

>It's still not quite clear what the actual harm is in shipping it since it's 1. actively maintained and 2. taken verbatim from Vim. If you don't want it, you can always let g:loaded_netrwPlugin = 1, same as any bundled plugin?

Or in reverse if you want a plugin you can just add it with your plugin-manager of choice. Also no harm in that. There are many other actively maintained plugins.

But of course if neovim rather wants to bundle plugins there are many other great plugins which I would like to suggest to bundle with neovim. Most of them should be maintained, there should be no harm bundling them with neovim and if you don't want them just disable them with *let g:loaded_someRandomPlugin = 1*. Here is a short list:

> airblade/vim-gitgutter, airblade/vim-rooter, AndrewRadev/switch.vim, Darazaki/indent-o-matic, farmergreg/vim-lastplace, hrsh7th/cmp-buffer, hrsh7th/cmp-nvim-lsp, hrsh7th/cmp-path, hrsh7th/nvim-cmp, hrsh7th/vim-vsnip, ibhagwan/fzf-lua, junegunn/fzf, kevinhwang91/nvim-bqf, machakann/vim-sandwich, mhinz/vim-grepper, michaeljsmith/vim-indent-object, nathom/tmux.nvim, neovim/nvim-lspconfig, numToStr/Comment.nvim, rbong/vim-flog, scrooloose/nerdtree, stevearc/stickybuf.nvim, stsewd/gx-extended.vim, svermeulen/vim-subversive, tpope/vim-eunuch, tpope/vim-fugitive, vijaymarupudi/nvim-fzf, wellle/targets.vim, windwp/nvim-autopairs

> But of course if neovim rather wants to bundle plugins

That's exactly what we want to do _less_ of, not more. Your list aptly illustrates why this too quickly becomes a slippery slope.

netrw does not follow the UNIX philosophy of "Do One Thing and Do It Well".

It does many things well, however users do not necessarily want all of its functionality.

**Use case:** use `scp://` but a different file browser.

**Suggestion:** make the netrw functionality modular and opt-out. In the above case a `g:netrw_browse_enable` setting would be useful.

> Some plugin or configuration may use netrw. Because it is builtin. So this is harder problem.

I'm not a NeoVim maintainer, but I don't think that NeoVim is Just a clone of Vim with extra Lua bindings. It's built to be better software, the backward compatibility doesn't matter right now.


It might be a problem if NeoVim went beyond version `1.0.0`, but now it doesn't. And even after that if there was something that will brake something, NeoVim can just go to `2.0.0`, it will not be a problem as long as it will improve NeoVim in general.

In the process of improving NeoVim, I don't think it's important to care that every plugin was ever made to work the same.
I don't even think it's a fantasy that vimscript it self will be abandoned someday in the future.

Thats way there is a #14090 issue.

Even the Linux Kernel, the most backward compatible software, where we have `Linus Torvalds`, some times we read that some drivers or technology has been abandoned/deleted.

Deleting `netrw` might even mean better stability and security in the future.

For example https://github.com/stevearc/oil.nvim [oil.nvim](https://this-week-in-neovim.org/2023/Jan/23#updates) makes netrw superfluous with remote server support for basic file operations.

I find `IMPROVING BROWSING			*netrw-listhack* *netrw-ssh-hack*` to be general useful.

1. I dont see yet a hackable/extensible plugin (lua functions usable by user) which offers the following functionality based on filepaths and integrates well into for example harpoon or another plugin:
```
    |netrw-a|	Hide marked files/directories
    |netrw-D|	Delete marked files/directories
    |netrw-ma|	Move marked files' names to |arglist|
    |netrw-mA|	Move |arglist| filenames to marked file list
    |netrw-mb|	Append marked files to bookmarks
    |netrw-mB|	Delete marked files from bookmarks
    |netrw-mc|	Copy marked files to target
    |netrw-md|	Apply vimdiff to marked files
    |netrw-me|	Edit marked files
    |netrw-mF|	Unmark marked files
    |netrw-mg|	Apply vimgrep to marked files
    |netrw-mm|	Move marked files to target
    |netrw-mp|	Print marked files
    |netrw-ms|	Netrw will source marked files
    |netrw-mt|	Set target for |netrw-mm| and |netrw-mc|
    |netrw-mT|	Generate tags using marked files
    |netrw-mv|	Apply vim command to marked files
    |netrw-mx|	Apply shell command to marked files
    |netrw-mX|	Apply shell command to marked files, en bloc
    |netrw-mz|	Compress/Decompress marked files
    |netrw-O|	Obtain marked files
    |netrw-R|	Rename marked files
```
2. file browsing like oil.nvim might have some non-extensible rough edges

> 1. I dont see yet a hackable/extensible plugin (lua functions usable by user) which offers the following functionality based on filepaths and integrates well into for example harpoon or another plugin:

https://github.com/justinmk/vim-dirvish provides the "marked files" functionality by leveraging the vim arglist. In a dirvish buffer, `x` "marks" file(s) by adding it to the arglist, then `:Shdo!` operates on the arglist.

milestone.description: Zero priority; no timeline. Promote an item from this state by taking ownership of it.
milestone.title: unplanned

title: Consider removing netrw in favor of dirvish
